Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: Okay, back into the 1960s, there was a research agency in the United States called DARPA, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: Actually, it was called ARPA at the time.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: They wanted to build this notion of a packet-switching network.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: Not a circuit switch network like a phone network where you get a dedicated path and a dedicated set of bandwidth and links from source to destination.

Speaker: Speaker 4 (College Student)
Utterance: So what would packet switching enable? I'm sure there's something big here, for sure.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: There's a lot big, right?

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: And so remember, this was a Department of Defense, was they wanted to have forms of of communication that were very robust, that were survivable.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: Packets could all find their own ways, be routed differently through the network.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: So if parts of the network failed, you could route around failures.

Speaker: Speaker 4 (College Student)
Utterance: Sounds like the reason for like a request response type of structure.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: So you can sort of see how the network architecture that wasn't designed to be 100% reliable inside the core of the network, and had that complexity built into the edges of the network.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: And to me, the really cool thing is you put this infrastructure in place, and then all these super creative people think about amazing things to build on top of it.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: And you see this proliferation of amazing applications.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: We talk about APIs, application programming interfaces.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: The API for the internet is something called a socket.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: And a socket simply says, I can communicate if I know your internet address, you know, 128.119.40.186, that number is the IP address of my server, the University of Massachusetts.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: It's called the Domain Name System.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: The DNS's role is to translate names like [gaia.cs.umass.edu](http://gaia.cs.umass.edu/), or [ibm.com](http://ibm.com/), or [facebook.com](http://facebook.com/) to an IP address so that your application can actually send a message to that name, to that named service.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: So in that sense, the internet is very decentralized, that the control of the network is up to whoever owns the network.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: The 2% where you said there's nobody in control, there's a little bit of centralized control.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: There's an organization called the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: Its responsibility is to handle, as the name ICANN suggests, names and numbers.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
Utterance: It's that little bit of centralization, central authority that you need.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Jim Kurose)
